OriginalSource.Creator: Terese Winslow
OriginalSource.Comment: Updated skin tone to FP III-IV
Breast in first panel changed to look like the ones in middle and third panels re size and coloration; Label "Tumor and sentinel lymph nodes removed" added to last panel.

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Sentinel lymph node biopsy of the breast; the first panel shows a radioactive substance and/or blue dye being injected near the tumor; the second panel shows that the injected material is followed visually and/or with a probe that detects radioactivity to find the sentinel nodes (the first lymph nodes to which cancer cells are likely to spread from a primary tumor); and the third panel shows the removal of the tumor and the sentinel nodes to check for cancer cells.

Captions.MediaCaption: Sentinel lymph node biopsy of the breast. A radioactive substance and/or blue dye is injected near the tumor (first panel). The injected material is followed visually and/or with a probe that detects radioactivity to find the sentinel nodes (the first lymph nodes to which cancer cells are likely to spread from a primary tumor) (second panel). The sentinel nodes are removed and checked for cancer cells (third panel). A sentinel lymph node biopsy is usually done at the same time the primary tumor is removed, but it can also be done before or after the tumor is removed.
